author: iSazonov
body:
## PR Summary

Use new .Net Core servicing build 2.0.5.
https://github.com/dotnet/cli/releases
https://blogs.msdn.microsoft.com/dotnet/2018/01/09/net-core-january-2018-update/

## PR Checklist

Note: Please mark anything not applicable to this PR `NA`.

- [x] [PR has a meaningful title](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-request---submission)
    - [x] Use the present tense and imperative mood when describing your changes
- [x] [Summarized changes](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-request---submission)

comments.author: markekraus
comments.body: Pleas push a commit with `[Feature]` in the commit message.

comments.author: bergmeister
comments.body:
Do we need to mention the 2 important security fixes that come with 2.0.5 in the documents?
- https://github.com/dotnet/announcements/issues/52
- https://github.com/dotnet/announcements/issues/51

Can someone review their severity/impact and decide whether this also means that 6.0 needs to have a patch with this update? @LeeHolmes

comments.author: bergmeister
comments.body: Should we also update the SDK in the [global.json](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/global.json) from `2.0.2` to `2.0.3`, which is already in the used AppVeyor image [VisualStudio2017](https://www.appveyor.com/docs/build-environment/)?

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body:
I think could we move to latest SDK (2.1.4) after GA 6.0.1 to get up to date the 6.0.0 servicing branch.

Interesting, will we be able to move to CoreFX 2.1.0 preview version in our development branch - this version already contains many performance improvements and we could use new C# 7.2.

comments.author: daxian-dbw
comments.body: @LeeHolmes @PaulHigin @SteveL-MSFT can you please take a look at the comment https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/pull/5903#issuecomment-357796209 and see if there's any implication on PS Core 6.0.0?

comments.author: SteveL-MSFT
comments.body: We should take dotnetcore 2.0.5 as part of 6.0.1 release

comments.author: bergmeister
comments.body: @SteveL-MSFT OK. On a related note: The WiX toolset also had a security patch 2 weeks ago: https://www.firegiant.com/blog/2017/12/31/wix-v3.10.4-and-wix-v3.11.1-released/

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body: It seems we use WiX from AppVeyor base image - so the issue is for AppVeyor.

comments.author: bergmeister
comments.body: Yes, but I guess that MSFT uses their own servers for building the GA release. This was a remark about the upcoming patch release.

comments.author: bergmeister
comments.body:
@iSazonov I am confused, the [global.json](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/global.json) still refers to `2.0.2` and the documentation on it [here](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/core/tools/global-json) says that this is the SDK (not the runtime version). This SDK version contains the old 2.0.0. version of the .Net Runtime, see docs [here](https://github.com/dotnet/core/blob/master/release-notes/download-archives/2.0.2-sdk-download.md)
Do we not need to update the string to `2.1.4`, which is the SDK containing the `2.0.5` runtime, see docs [here](https://github.com/dotnet/core/blob/master/release-notes/download-archives/2.0.5-download.md)?

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body:
@bergmeister It is a trick - we use different versions of runtime and CLI. See @daxian-dbw [comment](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/pull/5295#discussion_r148621920).
`RuntimeFrameworkVersion` really set minimal patch version of .Net Core runtime.
(I found great design docs https://github.com/dotnet/designs/issues/3)

What I would really like to see is that we could start using C# 7.2 and Span/Memory (used runtime 2.0.* already contains Span support).
Also interesting when we can use .Net Core 2.1.0 - they have already done a lot to increase performance and continue to increase it.

title: Update PowerShell to build with .NET Core 2.0.5
